newsitem.title: FINLAND: ERICSSON SEES BROADBAND MOBILE SYSTEM SOON.
newsitem.headline: ERICSSON SEES BROADBAND MOBILE SYSTEM SOON.

text.p: Swedish telecommunications giant Ericsson CEO Lars Ramqvist said on Thursday he expected a breakthrough soon in broadband mobile telecommunications systems, enabling video transmission.
He said Ericsson was cooperating strategically with other companies on standardisation, and that it was up to nations to decide which standards to implement.
"This will be a breakthrough very soon," Ramqvist told a news conference here. He did not elaborate.

Ericsson said in April it had agreed with Japan's NTT DoCoMo to jointly develop the first experimental third generation wireless communications system, and Ramqvist said it will be a broadband solution based on Code Division Multiple Access (CDMA) technology.
But he repetead that Ericsson did not plan to enter the market for old CDMA systems.
Commenting on when Ericsson may present a PDA (personal digital assistant) product, Ramqvist said the company had many potential PDA products but did not feel there was a market yet.
"We like to be in the leading edge, not in the bleeding edge," he said. "It is still not a real market."
Finnish rival Nokia last year launched the world's first digital handset, the Communicator which integrates a palmtop computer for the PDA market.
